0.title: Trunk Pride is Central to The Banks Journal Mantra
paragraphs: If there’s one modern brand in our world who’ve pinned their identity to the boardshorts they create then it’s Banks Journal.

1.title: the comfort stretch award four/three
paragraphs: The wetsuit for those who like their yoga in silk pants is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp. The Wetsuits entered into the Stretchiest and Comfiest 4/3mm category were:

2.title: champagne and caviar
paragraphs: The best lux suits over $450

3.title: the budget warrior (suits under $315)
paragraphs: The finest wetsuit for the frugal is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp

4.title: the fastest drying
paragraphs: All suits entered the fastest drying category, but after one use of the Rip Curl Heat Seeker featuring their Flashbomb lining, it was clear, no suit dries as fast as a Rip Curl.

5.title: feeling lovely (most stylish)
paragraphs: Like the fastest drying, every suit was entered into the best looking category. After careful analysis, the FERAL 4/3mm backzip was unanimously voted the sexiest wetsuit on the market.
Just like the 90’s, backzips are back!

0.title: Banks Journal
paragraphs: If there’s one modern brand in our world who’ve pinned their identity to the boardshorts they create then it’s Banks Journal.

And what a fine identity it is; few boxes get pilfered as quickly at Stab Hq a a fresh Banks Journal delivery. Banks Journal always manage to bring a certain wearable je ne sais quoi to their seasonal releases, and this year’s no different. Expect fresh takes on stripes, prints pulled from the most inventive of sources.

1.title: O'Neill
paragraphs: O’Neill’s heritage might be in rooted in rubber, but they’ve been making quality trunks for as long as anyone.

It’s a hard thing to define (or put a monetary value to) but O’Neill’s a brand that just has a ‘feel’, and their latest boardshort release is a true reflection of this. The perfect blend of tech, fit and aesthetics.

2.title: Quiksilver
paragraphs: Quik’s strength is rooted in their heritage, and those roots are firmly bolted to the core.

Type ‘Quiksilver 70s, 80s, 90s’ into the engine and enjoy the forward-thinking, obscure and damn-straight iconic trip through surf trunks in their many-splendoured forms. 2020 Quiksilver boardshorts are everything that’s good about being retrospective. Modern, wearable classics that tip the hat to the past, without forcing us to revisit what’s dated (TVC’s got a hell of a set of pins, I/you/we, do not).

3.title: Rip Curl Mens
paragraphs: If there’s a living, breathing exemplary ‘how to surf brand’ then it’s Rip Curl.

The Curl have managed to grow (large!) by sticking to the message, which is to surf and search, and produce the gear that allows you to do both. Whilst you’d sooner associate RC with wetsuits (and boy do they do a good job of those) their surfing’s quiet boardshort achiever, and their 2020 offering is everything the elemental surfer needs to surf long and hard in the temperate months.

4.title: Rip Curl Womens
paragraphs: If you need a bikini that’s going to fit and last surf after surf, then look no further than the female arm of the Curl.
This season sees floral prints and subtle cuts at the forefront; the perfect combination of feminine style, and surf practicality.

5.title: Roark
paragraphs: Can’t fault a brand with a clear message, and Roark’s couldn’t be plainer: hit the road.

Surfing and travel is an obvious connection, but there’s going to Indo every year and there’s hunting for icy slabs in Norway, or deserted wedges in some obscure corner of Africa. Roark personifies the latter, and the gear they make reflects as much. Their trunks are a nice blend of subtle tech, tasteful cuts (no high, no low) and prints stumbled upon in obscure markets around the globe. Roark's hallmark Boatman trunks even come with a lifetime guarantee, if you're in the market for some new old favourites.

6.title: Vans
paragraphs: The slumbering big dog of surf no more, Vans have launched a full-scale offensive at the surfing world.

And we’re all the richer for it. One of the few brands in our world with genuine mainstream reach, Vans surf is everything that's right with a big co run well. Their trunks are innovative, tasteful, but like the shoes that have served them so well, don't try and do too much. No gimmicks here, just trunks that you’ll buy, you’ll wear, and grow increasingly fond of over time.

7.title: Vissla
paragraphs: No longer a fresh face in our world, Vissla have woven their way into the fabric of surf through smart sponsorships and relentless devotion to quality.

The eclectic gaggle they sign monthly cheques for (from hi-fi flyers like Cam Richards to Bryce Young, Derrick Dis and beyond) have resulted in a diverse trunk output, and their latest batch is no different. Not afraid of colour (mmm peach) and with all the necessary frills.

8.title: Volcom Mens
paragraphs: Now one of our elder statesmen, it’s easy to forget in 2020 that once Volcom was the rudest brand in surf.

Back then trunks were long, and none longer than the Stone. It was Bruce and Gav and Dingo and man did us pre-millenials revere that iconic logo. The Stone might be older, potentially wiser, but they’re still deadly in the trunk dept. And they’re not afraid of a logo. If you’ve got a good one, like Volcom Stone, we implore you to use it.

9.title: Volcom Womens
paragraphs: Volcom Women’s brand identity is strong and refreshingly different from their male counterparts, but tied together it all makes sense.

Like two differently strong components to a relationship. Volcom favour a more fashion-forward approach to women’s swim, whilst ticking all the technical boxes when it comes to comfort in the surf. 2020 is all about daring one-pieces and 60s colour palates and really, what’s not to love?

10.title: Billabong Womens
paragraphs: Who has the most aspirational assembly women surfers on the planet? Bong women’s, 100x over. Beyond their beauty and grace in and out of the water, the Bong gals (an eclectic gaggle of some of surfing’’s most marketable, ripping and fun-loving women) seem to legit have the best time, and that comes through in the line. The prints are fun, the cuts are cheeky, and the result is femme surf at its finest.
